snippet: In two cases argued Tuesday, the justices wrestled with how long was too long to wait over the issue of an inmate’s mental competence.
abstract: Supreme Court, in a pair of cases, considers what to do when people convicted of capital crimes are mentally incompetent and so unable to help their lawyers with challenges to their convictions and sentences; justices, who appear to have little support for the indefinite stays of execution imposed by lower courts, wrestle with how long to limit the length of such stays.
lead_paragraph: In two cases argued Tuesday, the justices wrestled with how long was too long to wait over the issue of an inmate’s mental competence.

headline.seo: Supreme Court Considers Indefinite Stays of Execution for Mentally Incompetent Inmates
headline.main: Supreme Court Considers Indefinite Stays of Execution
headline.print_headline: Wrestling to Define the Indefinite Stays of Execution for Certain Inmates
